articles.headline: Latino Vote Turnout Likely to Lag, Poll Says
articles.snippet: Arizona’s immigration law may not bring the expected protest vote for Democrats, as just 51 percent of Latino registered voters say they will vote in November.
articles.abstract: Arizona’s immigration law may not bring the expected protest vote for Democrats, as just 51 percent of Latino registered voters say they will vote in November.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX  Arizona’s immigration law has prompted denunciations, demonstrations, boycotts and a federal lawsuit. But it may not bring the protest vote that many Democrats had hoped would stem a Republican onslaught in races across the country.

articles.headline: Sun Co-Founder Uses Capitalism to Help Poor
articles.snippet: Vinod Khosla invested heavily in a microfinance company, expecting it to profit poor people — and himself.
articles.abstract: Vinod Khosla invested heavily in a microfinance company, expecting it to profit poor people — and himself.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India  Vinod Khosla, the billionaire venture capitalist and co-founder of Sun Microsystems, was already among the world’s richest men when he invested a few years ago in SKS Microfinance, a lender to poor women in India.

articles.headline: For Those Near, the Miserable Hum of Clean Energy
articles.snippet: Lawsuits and complaints about turbine noise, vibrations and lost property value have cropped up in several states.
articles.abstract: Lawsuits and complaints about turbine noise, vibrations and lost property value have cropped up in several states.
articles.lead_paragraph: VINALHAVEN, Me. — Like nearly all of the residents on this island in Penobscot Bay, Art Lindgren and his wife, Cheryl, celebrated the arrival of three giant wind turbines late last year. That was before they were turned on.

articles.headline: Health Care’s Uneven Road to a New Era
articles.snippet: Soon Americans won’t have to pick between bad insurance or none. Until then, expect marketplace disruptions.
articles.abstract: Soon Americans won’t have to pick between bad insurance or none. Until then, expect marketplace disruptions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Consider what it would be like to have a health insurance plan that capped annual benefits at $2,000. For any medical care costing more than that, you would have to pay out of pocket.

articles.headline: Karzai’s Kin Use Ties to Gain Power in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: Dozens of relations and allies of President Hamid Karzai are forming a powerful oligarchy in government and business.
articles.abstract: Dozens of relations and allies of President Hamid Karzai are forming a powerful oligarchy in government and business.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Until recently, Taj Ayubi’s specialty was retail. Mr. Ayubi, an Afghan immigrant, ran a furniture store in Leesburg, Va., and before that, a thrift shop in Washington.

articles.headline: Foreclosure Furor Rises; Many Call for a Freeze
articles.snippet: Lawmakers in Washington requested a federal investigation into mortgage lenders’ practices, and Texas’s attorney general and others called for freezes on all foreclosures.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers in Washington requested a federal investigation into mortgage lenders’ practices, and Texas’s attorney general and others called for freezes on all foreclosures.
articles.lead_paragraph: The uproar over bad conduct by mortgage lenders intensified Tuesday, as lawmakers in Washington requested a federal investigation and the attorney general in Texas joined a chorus of state law enforcement figures calling for freezes on all foreclosures.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld and Gretchen Morgenson

articles.headline: At Flagging Tribune, Tales of a Bankrupt Culture
articles.snippet: Under Sam Zell, the Tribune Company was bankrupted by debt, and employees describe a profane and alienating workplace.
articles.abstract: Under Sam Zell, the Tribune Company was bankrupted by debt, and employees describe a profane and alienating workplace.
articles.lead_paragraph: In January 2008, soon after the venerable Tribune Company was sold for $8.2 billion, Randy Michaels, a new top executive, ran into several other senior colleagues at the InterContinental Hotel next to the Tribune Tower in Chicago.

articles.headline: Dim Outlook for Holiday Jobs
articles.snippet: Many retailers said they would barely increase their seasonal jobs from the low level of last year.
articles.abstract: Many retailers said they would barely increase their seasonal jobs from the low level of last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the economy sputters, prospects are dimming for unemployed workers who were banking on a seasonal retail job to carry them through the holidays.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Catherine Rampell

articles.headline: U.S. Apologizes as Attacks in Pakistan Continue
articles.snippet: Dozens of trucks were attacked as American officials apologized over a shooting that led to the border closing.
articles.abstract: Dozens of trucks were attacked as American officials apologized over a shooting that led to the border closing.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Dozens of tanker trucks carrying fuel to Afghanistan for NATO troops were torched near Quetta in western Pakistan on Wednesday, the third major attack on supplies since Pakistan closed a border crossing to Afghanistan a week ago and the first at the only checkpoint that remained open.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and Waqar Gillani
